chapter_1.title: Arjun Vishad Yog
chapter_1.summary: Arjuna, overwhelmed with sorrow and doubt, refuses to fight in the Kurukshetra war. He fears the consequences of killing his own relatives and teachers.
chapter_1.context: The great battle of Kurukshetra is about to begin. Arjuna, the mighty warrior, sees his own family members on both sides and becomes confused and emotionally weak.

key_verses.translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjay, what happened on the battlefield of Kurukshetra?
Arjuna said: My whole body trembles, my bow slips from my hand, and my skin burns as I see my relatives on this battlefield.
Having spoken thus, Arjuna, overwhelmed with sorrow, set aside his bow and sat down in the chariot.

teachings: Arjuna's dilemma represents the moral struggles we all face in life.
Fear and confusion arise when we let emotions cloud our duty.
It is important to seek guidance when we are uncertain.

chapter_2.title: Sankhya Yog
chapter_2.summary: Krishna introduces the concept of the eternal soul and explains why Arjuna must rise above his doubts and fight.
chapter_2.context: Krishna sees Arjuna’s sorrow and begins to impart spiritual wisdom, explaining the difference between the physical body and the eternal soul.

key_verses.translation: Just as the soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so also it passes into another body after death.
You have the right to perform your prescribed duties, but you are not entitled to the fruits of your actions.
Performing work skillfully and with detachment is the essence of yoga.

teachings: The soul is eternal and beyond physical death.
One must focus on performing duty, not on rewards.
Detachment from results leads to peace and self-realization.

chapter_3.title: Karma Yog
chapter_3.summary: Krishna explains the importance of selfless action and fulfilling one's duty without attachment.
chapter_3.context: Arjuna still hesitates. Krishna explains that action (karma) is necessary, and inaction is not an option for a warrior.

key_verses.translation: Work done as a sacrifice for the Supreme must be performed; otherwise, work causes bondage in this world.
Whatever great people do, others follow their example.

teachings: Selfless action (karma yoga) is the path to liberation.
Great leaders influence society through their actions.

chapter_4.title: Gyaan Karma Sanyas Yog
chapter_4.summary: Krishna reveals that he incarnates whenever righteousness declines and imparts divine knowledge.
chapter_4.context: Krishna explains the eternal cycle of righteousness and how selfless action leads to enlightenment.

key_verses.translation: Whenever righteousness declines and unrighteousness rises, I manifest myself to protect the good and destroy the evil.
To learn the truth, approach a spiritual teacher with humility and seek knowledge through service.

teachings: God takes form when righteousness declines.
True knowledge is attained by seeking wisdom from a guru.

chapter_5.title: Karma Sanyas Yog
chapter_5.summary: Krishna explains the difference between renunciation (sanyas) and selfless action (karma yoga).
chapter_5.context: Arjuna wonders if renunciation is superior to action. Krishna clarifies that action with detachment is the best path.

key_verses.translation: The wise see a learned Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, and even a dog equally.
Pleasures born of contact with the senses are temporary and lead to suffering.

teachings: Renunciation is not about avoiding duty but detaching from its fruits.
A wise person sees all beings as equal.
True happiness is beyond temporary pleasures.

chapter_6.title: Dhyana Yog
chapter_6.summary: Krishna explains meditation (dhyana) and the qualities of a true yogi.
chapter_6.context: Krishna now introduces the practice of meditation as a means to self-realization.

key_verses.translation: One must elevate oneself by one's own mind, not degrade oneself. The mind is a friend of the self, and also its enemy.
A yogi, meditating with a focused mind, attains peace and liberation.

teachings: Meditation leads to self-control and inner peace.
The mind can be our greatest friend or worst enemy.
A true yogi is disciplined, detached, and devoted.
